urn:contentItem:5Y7S-GX61-JCF9-44BF-00000-00The commission's digital strategy: More competition, less emissions2020-02-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:59ZLexisNexisThe commission's digital strategy: More competition, less emissionsPhilipp Grüll

In its digital strategy published on Wednesday (19 February), the European Commission committed itself to fostering 'Technology that works for the people' by increasing the digital prowess of European citizens and companies, doubling down on the market power of tech giants and tapping into ICT's potential for sustainability.

The document states that "businesses need a framework that allows them to start up, scale up, pool and use data, to innovate and compete or cooperate on fair terms".

To achieve this, the Commission plans to increase the competitiveness of European companies by improving their access to high-quality internet, data and digital skills on the one hand, and ironing out market-distorting advantages of competitors on the other.

Sharpening old tools

To safeguard fair competition, the Commission is ready to "use all instruments at its disposal" and vows to ensure that any player wanting to do business in the EU "accepts and respects our rules".

These rules must be the same offline and online, "from competition and single market rules, consumer protection, to intellectual property, taxation and workers' rights". European competition rules will undergo a "fitness check" for their applicability to the digital economy, including a review of state aid guidelines.

The strategy stresses that this will not only be done by writing new rules, but by enforcing old ones more effectively. To in turn support European companies in foreign markets, the Commission promises to address "unjustified restrictions" like data localisation requirements in third countries.

Hunting giants

With commissioner Margrethe Vestager at the helm, it is no surprise that the document takes aim at big tech companies with market power. Calling them "large private gatekeepers to markets, customers and information", the document emphasises that their "systemic role" must not endanger fair competition.

Where competition policy is not enough to address such systemic problems of the platform economy, the Commission would enact additional regulations, such as ex-ante rules, to "ensure contestability, fairness and innovation and the possibility of market entry" as well as protect public interests "beyond competition or economic considerations".

They would be proposed as part of the Digital Service Act Package, scheduled towards the end of the year, accompanied by a sector inquiry to identify obstacles to fair competition in the digital economy.

The Digital Services Act Package will also increase the responsibility of online platforms and information providers as well as strengthen the EU's oversight capabilities over their content policies.

On taxation of the digital realm, the strategy points out that profits of big digital players are often not taxed where they are generated, which further distorts competition. A communication on Business Taxation for the 21st century is announced without a specific time frame, which will take into account the progress of current negotiations at the OECD.

Getting people up to speed

To help European companies reap the benefits of digitalisation, the Commission outlines several supportive measures. Until 2021, investments into Europe's Gigabit connectivity will be sped up by a revision of regulations on broadband, 5G and 6G as well as radio spectrum policy.

This is supposed to help achieve the EU's connectivity goals: Gigabit connections for businesses (and public institutions like schools and hospitals) and at least 100 Mbps for households.

The EU executives' plans for digital skills will be strengthened through a reinforced Digital Education Action Plan, to be published this half of the year. To bolster cybersecurity, a European cybersecurity strategy has also been announced, albeit, again, without a timeline.

That will feature a newly-created joint Cybersecurity unit and a review of regulations on the Security of Network and Information Systems (NIS).

ICT for Future

Digital solutions will play a crucial role in the EU's ambitions to become climate neutral by 2050, states the strategy.

As the ICT sector accounts for 2% of global CO2 emissions (as much as air traffic) according to the document's data, with a potential increase to 14% by 2040, the Commission aims to make data centres and ICT infrastructure climate-neutral by 2030.

This will be complemented by updated regulations on device longevity and repairability, e.g. for smartphones.

For a cross-sectoral footprint decrease, the strategy outlines plans to use big data and AI for increasing efficiency and thus decreasing global emissions by a sevenfold. Tracking energy consumption could help predict when and where power is (and is not) needed.

Through precision farming, agricultural producers could, the Commission says, decrease their use of pesticides. Smart mobility could increase the efficiency of transport.

"This is a good start, but does not exploit the technical potential", German MEP Alexandra Geese said. While she approves of making the ITC-sector climate neutral, she added that "training algorithms with huge amounts of data consumes a great deal of energy" in the short-term, even if the goal of the algorithm is to have long-term increases in efficiency.

[Edited by Benjamin Fox]

Competition chief supremo Margrethe Vestager is likely to face questions over her dual role as both a commissioner and executive vice-president for Europe Fit for the Digital Age during her hearing in front of MEPs on Tuesday.

Her two new hats essentially will mix her competition powers and policymaking in the digital space.

In her mission letter to Ms Vestager, president-elect Ursula von der Leyen assigned the commissioner the role of driving industrial policy to help Europe lead in digital matters and have first-mover advantage on new technologies.

To carry out this mission she will enlist the help of Sylvie Goulard, the commissioner-designate for internal market, who has the mandate to boost Europe’s “technological sovereignty”.

Alongside Ms Vestager, they will both set standards for new technologies and 5G. This dual role, in the eyes of some, may prove tricky when Ms Vestager finds herself in a position when — on the one hand — she is looking to promote Europe as a leader in technology and — on the other — she is seeking to enforce competition for the benefit of consumers.

“The two approaches are conceptually different; competition enforcement requires neutrality towards the nationality of the firms in question, open-mindedness and confidentiality of proceedings,” writes Mathew Heim, visiting research fellow at the Bruegel think-tank. “Proposing of legislation includes structuring markets, seeking pre-determined outcomes, consultation and openness.”

Mr Heim adds: “We may have an incoming European Commission with a more directed industrial policy that may not sit well with traditional competition enforcement. What has changed is that the commissioner in charge of competition now also has an industrial policy function.”

Scepticism over her dual role has been dismissed by people close to Ms Vestager as “nonsense” and “a non question”.

The Dane, who Donald Trump has criticised and branded the “tax lady”, is also likely to face scrutiny over her plans to tackle big tech. She has already handed multibillion fines to tech giants including Google (more than €8bn) and Qualcomm (€1.2bn) and recently opened an investigation into Amazon’s dual role as both a market place and a seller of its own products.

She may tease out new ways in which she is hoping to go after US tech companies following news that the commission will impose so-called interim measures on Broadcom to force the chipmaker to cease alleged anti-competitive practices.

Ms Vestager is expected to see this case through the courts and — if successful — use this long-forgotten competition tool as a way to stop anti-competitive behaviour by agile tech companies before they cause “irreparable harm to competition”.

; @javierespFT

Hearings watch

 

Spain’s Josep Borrell, foreign policy chief in waiting, gave a characteristically trenchant performance at his European Parliament confirmation session. The veteran Spanish foreign minister warned the EU needed to stick together and pay more attention to the stability of its eastern neighbours if it wanted to be an international player in a world that had changed “for the worse” over the past decade. 

The former European Parliament president struck a careful line on Russia, while questions over past comments and conduct received only light attention (he said he did not think he had done anything wrong over a fine of €30,000 issued against him last year by Spain’s securities regulator for insider trading). MEPs' warm reception at the end suggested Mr Borrell’s confirmation was unlikely to face serious opposition from the institution he once headed. ( FT)

Meanwhile the Czech Republic's Vera Jourova, nominee for vice-president for values and transparency, sailed through her hearing without problems.

Coming up on Tuesday are the three vice-presidents from the three main groups: the EPP’s Valdis Dombrovskis from Latvia (0900), Ms Vestager from the liberals (1430) and Dutch socialist Frans Timmermans (1830).

Chart du jour: thrifty Remainers

UK retails have suffered their worst September for sales in 20 years as British consumers — led by cautious Remainers — tighten the purse strings. ( chart via FT)

Planet Europe 

Syria turmoil 
Donald Trump’s threat to “obliterate” Turkey’s economy should it do anything he considered “off limits” sent the lira sliding to its lowest level against the dollar in more than a month. It capped a turbulent day that began with news Mr Trump planned to stand US troops aside, apparently giving a green light to a Turkish military operation in north-east Syria against the Kurds — crucial US allies in the fight against Isis. Meanwhile EU countries were sweating on what would happen if their nationals detained in northern Syria for allegedly fighting for Isis were freed. ( WaPo)

Pick up the lingo
FT columnist Gideon Rachman anticipated Josep Borrell’s argument that the EU must learn to “use the language of power”, in this column published on the very afternoon of the confirmation hearing. (FT)

Costa living
Portugal’s prime minister António Costa hailed the success of the “geringonça” — unlikely contraption — minority government he has led, as he prepared for coalition talks to turn his Socialist party’s improved showing in Sunday's elections into a viable administration. ( FT)

Climate rally 
Thousands of climate-change protesters took to the streets in cities around the world on Monday to launch two weeks of peaceful civil disobedience. Police arrested more than 250 in the UK and more than 100 in the Netherlands. ( Reuters)

Poland’s offer
Poland’s ruling Law and Justice government is offering a sharply higher minimum wage if it wins re-election on Sunday — renewing its vote-winning platform of support for the poor but setting the country’s businesses on edge. “We want to close the chapter [in which Poland was] a country of low wages and cheap labour,” Poland’s prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, told Poland’s state press agency. ( FT)

German slowdown
German industrial orders have continued their decline, dropping by 0.6 per cent in August from the previous month and adding to the gloom hanging over the eurozone’s biggest economy. ( FT).

French protest
Demonstrators are due to take to the streets on Tuesday to rally against contentious pension reforms. (Le Figaro)
